data.title: Atom is spawning multiple processes and hangs/freezes when clicking inside the Tree View
data.body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

Atom hangs when there is multiple project folders.

A new process spawns every couple seconds with the following command line, taking 10% cpu, then spawns a another of the same process, one per project folder. Atom hangs for approximately 2 seconds x # of project folders : atom.exe --eval require('C:\\Users\\<username>\\AppData\\Local\\atom\\app-1.13.0\\resources\\app.asar\\src\\compile-cache.js').setCacheDirectory('C:\\Users\\e018503\\.atom\\compile-cache'); require('C:\\Users\\<username>\\AppData\\Local\\atom\\app-1.13.0\\resources\\app.asar\\src\\task-bootstrap.js');

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Interact with atom by clicking in atom window or entering Ctrl+Shift+P

**Expected behavior:** Processes may spawn but Atom is responsive

**Actual behavior:** A new process spawns every couple seconds with the following command line, taking 10% cpu, then spawns a another of the same process, one per project folder. Atom hangs for approximately 2 seconds x # of project folders : 
`atom.exe --eval require('C:\\Users\\<username>\\AppData\\Local\\atom\\app-1.13.0\\resources\\app.asar\\src\\compile-cache.js').setCacheDirectory('C:\\Users\\e018503\\.atom\\compile-cache'); require('C:\\Users\\<username>\\AppData\\Local\\atom\\app-1.13.0\\resources\\app.asar\\src\\task-bootstrap.js');`

**Reproduces how often:** Reproducible every minute or so. After the issue occurs normal operation continues for a couple minutes.

### Versions

Atom    : 1.13.0
Electron: 1.3.13
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0
OS: Windows 7 x64

### Additional Information

This was reproducible in safe mode, after clearing window state, and after disabling all community add-ons.

data.title: Atom does not run properly on the Ubuntu 16.10 (x86)
data.body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

Dear all,

I am trying to use Atom on 32 bit virtual machine running Ubuntu 16.10 as guest virtual machine OS (I am using latest version of VirtualBox 5.1.12 on Windows 10).

I have tried both options - using pre-compiled 32 bit binary package provided by webupd8.org and compiling binary within virtual machine myself. Both steps lead to the same result so I will describe symptoms for observed behavior when building 32-bit Atom locally as this may be more pristine state.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. I was able to successfully compile Atom on Ubuntu using `script/build --create-debian-package` command. DEB package is successfully created and build is clean with no errors. 
2. Installing Atom.deb - success, no issues
3. Atom --version
```
Atom    : 1.13.0
Electron: 1.3.13
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0
```

**Expected behavior:** I would expect editor to launch

**Actual behavior:** Atom editor is dark (black), nothing can be seen within text area. Title bar shows "Welcome Guide -- Atom" but whole text area is black and nothing can be seen. Moving mouse within the text area changes cursor pointer from time to time so it seems that pane boundaries within the text area are properly recognized but not properly rendered (everything is black as mentioned above). Attempt to close all tabs through menu option (File\Close Tab) does not solve the issue, while tabs are closed which can be observed by text changing within Atom's window Title bar, but whole text area continues to be black\dark.

**Reproduces how often:** Every time Atom is launched

## Versions

```
Atom    : 1.13.0
Electron: 1.3.13
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0
```

### Additional Information

This is how Atom screen looks like:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/8009260/21987607/87f2e806-dc04-11e6-975e-8d956088c3c1.png)

data.title: Losslessly optimize all images with imgult.
data.body:
https://imgult.github.io

Signed-off-by: Ryan P.C. McQuen <ryanpcmcquen@member.fsf.org>


### Description of the Change

All images were losslessly optimized with [imgult](https://github.com/ryanpcmcquen/image-ultimator).

Compare the original size:
`355` KB => https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/resources/app-icons/beta/png/1024.png

![before_imgult](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/772937/21987123/0a01024a-dbb7-11e6-93a2-7861d2c42439.png)


To the _imgulted_ size:
`131` KB => https://github.com/ryanpcmcquen/atom/blob/master/resources/app-icons/beta/png/1024.png

![after_imgult](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/772937/21987129/10292d14-dbb7-11e6-883a-2330576cd5d7.png)


### Why Should This Be In Core?

It's part of the core.

### Benefits

Less disk space used for images that look identical!

### Possible Drawbacks

None are obvious.

data.title: Autocompletion eats return key presses while typing
data.body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

Autocompletion sometimes eats return key presses for me while typing. This interferes with the typing of legitimate proper code in many languages. In C/C++ the impact is less serious because a line is *usually* terminated with a `;` (but midstatement line breaks are possible and sometimes used for formatting, so this could also lead to user frustrations). However, for languages where an identifier can regularly be at the end of the line, as for example in lua or when assigning one variable to another in Python, this is potentially very wrong and frustrating.

The autocompletion should be configured in a way that if the user doesn't actively interact (e.g. choose something out of the list with active key presses) it will never mess up what the user typed, unless it is most likely a proper useful macro (e.g. "pdb" in Python) which is intended to be expanded in special ways.
### Steps to Reproduce


1. Start typing some identifier/variable name you used before in the same file
2. The autocompletion should suggest it to you while you type the name. Don't press any cursor keys and don't actively interact with it in any way
3. Press return key to start a new line after typing the identifier

**Expected behavior:** Auto-complete popup closes, cursor ends up in new line

**Actual behavior:** Auto-complete popup closes, cursor does *not* end up in new line

**Reproduces how often:** 100% (every time)

### Versions

```
[jonas@falcon ~]$ atom --version
Atom    : 1.10.2
Electron: 0.37.8
Chrome  : 49.0.2623.75
Node    : 5.10.0
[jonas@falcon ~]$ apm --version
apm  1.12.5
npm  3.10.5
node 4.4.5
python 2.7.12
git 2.9.3
[jonas@falcon ~]$ uname -a
Linux falcon 4.8.16-300.fc25.x86_64 #1 SMP Fri Jan 6 18:11:49 UTC 2017 x86_64 x86_64 x86_64 GNU/Linux
[jonas@falcon ~]$
```

### Additional Information

Any additional information, configuration or data that might be necessary to reproduce the issue.

data.title: Atom uses cson very extensively, but there is no formal specification for cson
data.body:
Atom appears to use the cson format very extensively. However, there appears to be no formal specification for cson available at all.

Given how prominently Atom uses this format, this is rather undesirable. Maybe the Atom develoeprs could convince the CSON maintainers that a formal specification would be important? (or maybe even help them out with it) This issue appears to have been brought up multiple times on the [CSON issues tracker](https://github.com/bevry/cson/issues) (most recently by myself), but so far there appears to be still no specification available or even any sort of publicly stated commitment to provide one in the near future.

data.title: It's impossible to run Electron or Electron apps from within Atom
data.body:
This appears to have been floating around everywhere except here. @Fred-Barclay did some [investigation](https://discuss.atom.io/t/atom-command-does-not-work-in-atom-terminal-packages/37627) and made an extensive post on the forums.

> From Linux:
```
$ atom AUTHORS
$ electron: bad option: --app=/usr/lib/atom
electron: bad option: --executed-from=/home/fred/Git/Termination
electron: bad option: --pid=3824
```

> From macOS:
```
LSOpenURLsWithRole() failed for the application /Applications/Atom.app with error -10810.
projects $ atom README.md
LSOpenURLsWithRole() failed for the application /Applications/Atom.app with error -10810.
```

> After doing some digging it appears that electron is being set to run as node (and then this affects Atom - I'm not sure exactly how yet) so that when atom is passed into the terminal, node is called instead. You can see this when you compare the output of commands run inside termination:

```
$ atom --version 
v6.5.0
$ electron --version
v6.5.0
$ node --version
v7.3.0
```
> to commands run in a dedicated system terminal

```
$ atom --version
Atom    : 1.12.7
Electron: 1.4.13
Chrome  : 53.0.2785.143
Node    : 6.5.0
$ electron --version
v1.4.13
$ node --version
v7.3.0
```

On Windows 10, I am not able to execute or see any error messages regarding Atom or the other program I've been testing this with (GitKraken); `atom --version` just bumps me back to the prompt when used from within Atom.

On `platformio-ide-terminal`, @jbrodriguez [posted on November 11](https://github.com/platformio/platformio-atom-ide-terminal/issues/103) that it used to work and stopped working following an update. In the same thread, @BenSjoberg [found a solution](https://github.com/platformio/platformio-atom-ide-terminal/issues/103#issuecomment-271672093) for Unix machines, and running the command with `sudo` _may_ work (see that thread).

data.title: pre

data.title: Missing libnode.dylib - OSX Sierra Crash on start
data.body:
Hi,

Let me first thank you for the great job of making Atom, I was using it as my LaTeX editor, thus far the best.

Unfortunately, today Atom stopped working. It crashes on start. **Trying to run in Safe Mode results in the same crash.**

Here are the details:

The crash report indicates a dylib is missing. I was not able to find the libnode.dylib file inside the path indicated in the crash report and I could not locate it anywhere inside Atom.app. I don't understand the problem since I did not update macOS nor Atom after the last time I used Atom. Searching the web, it seems that this is a consistent issue for Atom in OSX for at least two years now, as users have being reporting this weird crash on start behavior caused by the missing lib for several OSX versions and Atom versions. In my case, Atom was working fine and I cannot identify what caused the app to stop working suddenly.

> Process:               Atom [23854]
> Path:                  /Applications/Atom.app/Contents/MacOS/Atom
> Identifier:            com.github.atom
> Version:               1.13.0 (1.13.0)
> Code Type:             X86-64 (Native)

>

> [...]
>

data.title: More title-bar options (macOS)
data.body:
### Description of the Change

This replaces the current "Use Custom Title Bar" checkbox with a "Title Bar" dropdown. It has the following options:

- `native` (default)
- `custom` adapts to themes
- `custom-inset`  **New**! has more padding
- `hidden` **New**! completely hidden

![screen shot 2017-01-14 at 4 30 55 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/378023/21953310/dbd0c716-da76-11e6-8abd-62d7ba54033e.png)

#### Native

![title-bar](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/378023/21953492/4a89d846-da7c-11e6-87ec-77f2125fc32e.png)

#### Custom

![title-bar 2](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/378023/21953491/4a88f020-da7c-11e6-98eb-0416edce2a21.png)

#### Custom Inset (new)

![title-bar 3](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/378023/21953493/4a8b4b36-da7c-11e6-9938-7ffc62e8e495.png)

#### Hidden (new)

![title-bar 4](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/378023/21953494/4a8c607a-da7c-11e6-8ffa-2400c07e1233.png)


### Alternate Designs

I also tried to add a "hide title-bar but keep the traffic lights" option:

![title-bar-custom](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/378023/18807178/79a7a210-827b-11e6-8f96-6b2a9bf28b02.png)

Unfortunately there are a few [edge cases](https://github.com/atom/atom/pull/10208#issuecomment-248550174) that would make the UI look broken. It's something that a [package](https://atom.io/packages/no-title-bar), theme or `styles.less` could provide when `custom-inset` is used.

Another example with the `tool-bar` package taking the role of a "title bar":

![title-bar-custom 2](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/378023/18807177/79a71afc-827b-11e6-8bc9-68ec69338e59.png)


### Why Should This Be In Core?

Needs access to the `BrowserWindow` API.


### Benefits

- Provides more title-bar variations.
- Themes can adapt to the different title-bar modes. Before there was no way to tell.
- Allows packages/themes to customize even further, like hide the title-bar but keep the traffic lights.


### Possible Drawbacks

When hiding the title-bar, managing the window needs to be done with the keyboard or from the menu. Dragging the window needs to be done with the status-bar. Not really a drawback since it's a choice and not the default.


### Applicable Issues

This PR contiues from https://github.com/atom/atom/pull/10208 (Hide title bar on OS X) and https://github.com/atom/atom/pull/11790 (already merged).

/cc @atom/feedback @atom/design

data.title: GIRL Emoji with the FITZ-3 modifier rendering as two separate characters
data.body:
[Description of the issue]

The GIRL Emoji with the FITZ-3 modifier, which renders correctly according to the Unicode specification in Chromium as a FITZ-3 GIRL , renders as default GIRL emoji followed separately by a square showing the FITZ-3 skin tone.

### Steps to Reproduce

0. Have an Emoji font that supports the Fitzpatrick modifiers installed.  I'm using Google's Noto Color Emoji from https://noto-website-2.storage.googleapis.com/pkgs/Noto-hinted.zip
1. Open a shell in a terminal emulator.  I'm using ZSH in Guake
2. Run Atom from your shell.  I'm doing this as `atom --clear-window-state --safe`
3. Open Chromium
4. In Chromium go to https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Emoji#Skin_color
5. Select the FITZ-3 GIRL as shown here: ![screenshot4](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2502960/21948798/3c01154e-d9a2-11e6-88da-eed671baf07f.png)

6. Copy with Ctrl+C
7. Switch to Atom
8. Create a new document in Atom with Ctrl+N
9. Paste with Ctrl+V

**Expected behavior:** FITZ-3 GIRL is rendered according to the Unicode specification, as Chromium does as shown here: ![screenshot2](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2502960/21948334/5d7f5cf6-d99f-11e6-919f-ba40670da3eb.png) 

**Actual behavior:** The default GIRL emoji followed by seperate FITZ-3 modifier is shown as shown here: ![screenshot5](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2502960/21948848/93aa9720-d9a2-11e6-9c87-f95e1bccf823.png)

**Reproduces how often:** Every time

### Versions
Atom version info:
Atom    : 1.13.0
Electron: 1.3.13
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0

apm  1.14.1
npm  3.10.5
node 4.4.5
python 2.7.12+
git 2.9.3

OS info:
Distributor ID:	Ubuntu
Description:	Ubuntu 16.10
Release:	16.10
Codename:	yakkety

### Additional Information

I doubt these matter, but the issue posting guide says I should include them:

I have not installed any packages after installing Atom
I just installed Atom for the first time, and as such have not tested this on other versions.
I have not changed any Atom configuration files.
I only have one monitor.
I use the us-dvorak keyboard layout.

Please let me know if there is something else I should include.

data.title: Normalize disk drive letter in path on Windows
data.body:
### Description of the Change

Currently atom creates two buffers for the same file if passed paths use difference case for disk drive letter, e.g. `d:\file.txt` and `D:\file.txt`

This change ensures that the absolute path always has disk drive letter in uppercase. 

### Alternate Designs

The other place where this fix could be applied is [findBufferForPath](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/src/project.coffee#L331) function. However the used function [resolvePath](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/src/project.coffee#L229) already has some path normalization code, so I think this is the best fit.

Actually Windows interpreters `file.txt` and `File.txt` as the same file. Maybe it makes sense to extend this patch and make Atom to do the same on this operation system, but I'm not sure because it can be file system specific. Any suggestions are welcome!

### Why Should This Be In Core?

I believe the current behavior of the editor is wrong for Windows users, so it makes no sense to create a plugin to fix that.

### Benefits

The main benefit I would like to get is the ability to click on parsed backtrace in my terminal emulation app (ConEmu). Right now it works, but atom opens second buffer for the same file because it doesn't normalize disk drive letter.

### Possible Drawbacks

The possible drawback is some broken tests, but I've checked that and it seems everything works.

### Applicable Issues

Here is the related issue #8221. It's not exactly about my problem, but it's very near.

data.title: Allow searching a string in installed packages information
data.body:
*Problems*

- changing a setting/shortcut requires to find the installed package it's supposed to belong to (can be tricky at times, it's a bit time consuming), scroll down and find the term by eye;
- sometimes people [assume you know where to find a certain setting](https://github.com/richrace/highlight-selected/issues/73#issuecomment-104724559) and if not the case you have to search it on the web, which is time consuming;

*Proposal*

Allow searching terms in all of the installed packages by looking up:

- package settings' name and description (and maybe setting's allowed values?)
- package keybindings' command, selector and source 
- eventually, package name and description
- eventually, package READMEs

---
(on Atom 1.13.0 now)

data.title: Atom prompts to upgrade from Beta to Stable channel, breaking install on Windows
data.body:
### Description

After starting build 1.13.0-beta8 and clicking ```Restart and install``` to update to build 1.14.0-beta0 Atom restarted but prompted me to update again. Without checking the version number I clicked update again and just after doing so noticed I was on the version I intended to update to. The one listed that I was now going to update to was a lower version number. This resulted in the Atom shortcut in Windows being changed from ```AppData\Local\atom\Update.exe --processStart "atom.exe"``` to ```AppData\Local\atom\atom.exe``` and breaking the shortcut as that file does not exist.

To temporarily workaround this issue I had to restore both my Atom install folder and my desktop from a windows shadow copy created before the Atom update took place. Then disable the auto download and update within Atom to prevent it from entering the broken state again.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Launch Atom 1.13.0-beta8
2. Select Restart & Install Update to update to Atom 1.14.0-beta0
3. Once Atom restarts observe it prompts a notification to update to a "newer" version again
4. Observe the "newer" version, which appears to be listed as the current stable branch version, is lower than currently installed version (if Atuomatically download updates is checked, in my case it is) observe that Atom will begin to download the "new update" automatically.
5. Select Restart and install
6. Once Atom restarts, exit it and observe the Windows shortcut is now directing to an invalid path
7. Go to where Atom's shortcut is now pointing to: ```AppData\Local\atom\atom.exe``` and observe that there is no atom.exe and both versions of Atom are listed in the directory.

**Expected behavior:** Atom does not incorrectly prompt to update to an older version of Atom that ends up breaking your install.

**Actual behavior:** Atom fails to install the older version and breaks the current install.

**Reproduces how often:** The initial issue happened once (unable to recreate the situation to do it again. However, selecting to "update" when prompted to after directly running Atom from ```AppData\Local\atom\app-1.14.0-beta0\atom.exe``` results in the same failed update and continues to keep the install broken.

### Versions
Atom    : 1.14.0-beta0
Electron: 1.3.13
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0

Windows 7 Ultimate 64bit

### Additional Information
